questiontext.text:
Exercise

If \(\displaystyle{v=\sqrt{\frac{@a*x@}{@b*y@}}}\) find the maximum percentage error in \(v\) due to errors of \({@error_x@} \%\) in \(x\) and \({@error_y@} \% \) in \(y\).

The maximum percentage error in \(v\) is [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]%.

generalfeedback.text:
We are given the funtcion \(\displaystyle{v=\sqrt{\frac{@a*x@}{@b*y@}}}\) and \(x, y\) are subject to percentage relative errors of \({@error_x@} \%\) and \({@error_y@} \%\) respectively.

First, find \(\dfrac{\partial v}{\partial x}\) and \(\dfrac{\partial x}{\partial y}.\)

\(\dfrac{\partial v}{\partial x} = \displaystyle{ {@v_x@}}\)

\(\dfrac{\partial v}{\partial y} = \displaystyle{ {@v_y@}}\)

Now we write down the expression of \( \delta v .\)

\[ \left|\delta v \right|_{\text{max}} \simeq \left| \frac{\partial v}{\partial x} \right| \left| \delta x \right|+ \left| \frac{\partial v}{\partial y} \right| \left| \delta y \right| \simeq \left| {@v_x@} \right| \left| \delta x \right| + \left| {@v_y@} \right| \left| \delta y \right| \]

Hence we write down an expression for the percentage relative error in \(f\):

\[ \begin{align} \dfrac{\delta v}{v} \times 100 & \simeq \left| {@v_x@} \times \sqrt{\frac{@b*y@}{@a*x@}} \, \delta x \times 100 \right| + \left| {@v_y@} \times \sqrt{\frac{@b*y@}{@a*x@}} \, \delta y \times 100 \right| \\ & \simeq \left| {@v1@} \delta x \times 100 \right| + \left| {@v2@} \delta y \times 100 \right| \end{align}\]

The percentage relative errors of \(x,y \) are \({@error_x@} \%\) and \({@error_y@} \%\) respectivelly so:

\( \displaystyle \frac{\delta x}{x} = {@error_x@} \) and

\( \displaystyle \frac{\delta y}{y} = {@error_y@} \)

Substituting them into the previous relation we find:
\[\dfrac{\delta v}{v} \times 100 \simeq \left| {@v1@} \delta x \times 100 \right| + \left| {@v2@} \delta y \times 100 \right| = \frac{{@error_x@}}{2} +\frac{{@error_y@}}{2} ={@ta1@} \%\]

Alterantive method:

If we first take logarithms of both sides \[\ln v = \frac{1}{2}\ln {@a@} + \frac{1}{2} \ln x - \frac{1}{2} \ln {@b@} - \frac{1}{2} \ln y\]

We can then apply the total derivative (implicitly) to obtain

\[\frac1v \mathrm{d}v= \frac{1}{2x}\mathrm{d}x-\frac{1}{2y}\mathrm{d}y\]

So \(\dfrac{\delta v}{v} \approx \dfrac{\delta x}{2x}- \dfrac{\delta y}{2y}\)

The maximum percentage error in \(v\) is therefore \[v=\left|\frac{\delta x}{2x}\right|+\left|-\frac{\delta y}{2y}\right|= \frac{{@error_x@}}{2} +\frac{{@error_y@}}{2} = {@ta1@} \% \]
